tool.name: Filter
tool.description: BAM datasets on a variety of attributes
tool.command:
cat $script_file > $out_file2;
#for $bam_count, $input_bam in enumerate( $input_bams ): ln -s "${input_bam.input_bam}" "localbam_${bam_count}.bam" && ln -s "${input_bam.input_bam.metadata.bam_index}" "localbam_${bam_count}.bam.bai" && #end for
bamtools filter -script $script_file
#for $bam_count, $input_bam in enumerate( $input_bams ): -in "localbam_${bam_count}.bam" #end for -out $out_file1

param.name: bam_property_selector
param.label: Select BAM property to filter on

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on this alignment flag
param.help: Default (3) is for a paired read mapped in a proper pair

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on this CIGAR string
param.help: Default (101M) is for 101 continuously matched bases

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on inster size
param.help: You can use >, <, =, and ! (not) in your expression. E.g., to select pairs with inster size above 250 nt use ">=250"

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select reads makwed as duplicates
param.help: Checked = Read IS Duplicate, Empty = Read is NOT Duplicate

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select reads failing QC
param.help: Checked = Failed QC, Empty = Passed QC

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select first mate in a read pair
param.help: Checked = is first mate, Empty = is NOT first mate

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Selected mapped reads
param.help: Checked = Mapped, Empty = NOT mapped

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select reads with mapped mate
param.help: Checked = Mate IS mapped Empty = Mate is NOT mapped

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select reads with mate on the reverse strand
param.help: Checked = Mate IS on reverse strand, Empty = Mate is NOT on the reverse strand

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select paired reads
param.help: Checked = Read IS paired, Empty = Read is NOT paired

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select BAM records for primary alignments
param.help: Checked = Alignment IS primary, Empty = Alignment is NOT primary

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select properly paired reads
param.help: Checked = Read IS in proper pair, Empty = Read is NOT in the proper pair

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select reads in the reverse strand only
param.help: Checked = Read IS on the reverse strand, Empty = Read is NOT on the reverse strand

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Select second mate in a read pair
param.help: Checked = Read IS second mate, Empty = Read is NOT second mate

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on read mapping quality (phred scale)
param.help: You can use >, <, =, and ! (not) in your expression. E.g., to select reads with mapping quality of at least 30 use ">=30"

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on the position of the mate
param.help: You can use >, <, =, and ! (not) in your expression. E.g., to select reads with mate (second end) mapping after position 1,000,000 use ">1000000"

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on reference name for the mate
param.help: You can use = and ! (not) in your expression. E.g., to select reads with mates mapping to chrM use "chr22"

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on read name
param.help: You can use = and ! (not) in your expression.

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on the position of the read
param.help: You can use >, <, =, and ! (not) in your expression. E.g., to select reads mapping after position 5,000 use ">5000"

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on a sequence motif
param.help: You can use ! (not) in your expression

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on the reference name for the read
param.help: You can use ! (not) in your expression

param.name: bam_property_value
param.label: Filter on a particular tag
param.help: You can use >, <, =, and ! (not). Tag name and its value must be separated by ":". E.g., to obtain reads with at least one mismatch use "NM:>1"

param.name: rules_selector
param.label: Would you like to set rules?
param.help: Allows complex logical constructs. See Example 4 below.

param.name: rules
param.label: Enter rules here
param.help: This option can only be used with at least two conditions. Read help below (Example 4) to understand how it works.

tool.help:
**What is does**
BAMTools filter is a very powerful utility to perform complex filtering of BAM files. It is based on BAMtools suite of tools by Derek Barnett (https://github.com/pezmaster31/bamtools).
-----
**How it works**
The tool use logic relies on the three concepts: (1) input BAM, (2) groups, and (3) filters.
*Input BAM(s)*
The input BAM is self-explanatory. This is the dataset you will be filtering. The tool can accept just one or multiple BAM files. To filter on multiple BAMs just add them by clicking **Add new BAM dataset(s) to filter**
*Conditions and Filters*
Conditions for filtering BAM files can be arranged in **Groups and Filters**. While it can be confusing at first this is what gives ultimate power to this tools. So try to look at the examples we are supplying below.
-----
**Example 1. Using a single filter**
When filtering on a single condition there is no need to worry about filters and conditions. Just choose a filter from the **Select BAM property to filter on:** dropdown and enter a value (or click a checkbox for binary filters). For example, for retaining reads with mapping quality of at least 20 one would set the tool interface as shown below:
.. image:: ${static_path}/images/single-filter.png
-----
**Example 2. Using multiple filters**
Now suppose one needs to extract reads that (1) have mapping quality of at least 20, (2) contain at least 1 mismatch, and (3) are mapping onto forward strand only. To do so we will use three filters as shown below (multiple filters are added to the interface by clicking on the **Add new Filter** button):
.. image:: ${static_path}/images/multiple-filters.png
In this case (you can see that the three filters are grouped within a single Condition - **Condition 1**) the filter too use logical **AND** to perform filtering. In other words only reads that (1) have mapping quality of at least 20 **AND** (2) contain at least 1 mismatch **AND** are mapping onto forward strand will be returned in this example.
-----
**Example 3. Complex filtering with multiple conditions**
Suppose now you would like to select **either** reads that (**1**) have (*1.1*) no mismatches and (*1.2*) are on the forward strand **OR** (**2**) reads that have (*2.1*) at least one mismatch and (*2.2*) are on the reverse strand. In this scenario we have to set up two conditions: (**1**) and (**2**) each with two filters: *1.1* and *1.2* as well as *2.1* and *2.2*. The following screenshot expalins how this can be done:
.. image:: ${static_path}/images/complex-filters.png
-----
**Example 4. Even more complex filtering with Rules**
In the above example we have used two conditions (Condition 1 and Condition 2). Using multiple conditions allows to combine them and a variety of ways to enable even more powerful filtering. For example, suppose get all reads that (**1**) do NOT map to mitochondria and either (**2**) have mapping quality over 20, or (**3**) are in properly mapped pairs. The logical rule to enable such filtering will look like this::
!(1) & (2 | 3)
Here, numbers 1, 2, and 3 represent conditions. The following screenshot illustrates how to do this in Galaxy:
.. image:: ${static_path}/images/rule.png
There are three conditions here, each with a single filter. A text entry area that can be opened by clicking on the **Would you like to set rules?** checkbox enables you to enter a rule. Here numbers correspond to numbers of conditions as they are shown in the interface. E.g., 1 corresponds to condition 1, 2 to condition 2 and so on... In human language this means::
NOT condition 1 AND (condition 2 OR condition 3)
-----
**JSON script file**
This tool produces two outputs. One of the them is a BAM file containing filtered reads. The other is a JSONified script. It can help you to see how your instructions are sent to BAMTools. For instance, the example 4 looks like this in the JSON form::
{ "filters": [ { "id": "1", "tag":"NM:=0", "isReverseStrand":"false" }, { "id": "2", "tag":"NM:>0", "isReverseStrand":"true" } ] }
-----
**More information**
.. class:: infomark
Additional information about BAMtools can be found at https://github.com/pezmaster31/bamtools/wiki
